Available online 20 October 2024 Review CO2-assisted oxidation dehydrogenation of light alkanes over metal-based heterogeneous catalysts Yingbin Zheng a b 1 Xinbao Zhang a 1 Junjie Li a Jie An a Longya Xu a Xiujie Li a * Xiangxue Zhu a * a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China * Corresponding author 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Light olefins are important platform feedstocks in the petrochemical industry, and the ongoing global economic development has driven sustained growth in demand for these compounds. The dehydrogenation of alkanes, derived from shale gas, serves as an alternative olefins production route. Concurrently, the target of realizing carbon neutrality promotes the comprehensive utilization of greenhouse gas. The integrated process of light alkanes dehydrogenation and carbon dioxide reduction (CO2-ODH) can produce light olefins and realize resource utilization of CO2, which has gained wide popularity. With the introduction of CO2, coke deposition and metal reduction encountered in alkanes dehydrogenation reactions can be effectively suppressed. CO2-assisted alkanes dehydrogenation can also reduce the risk of potential explosion hazard associated with O2-oxidative dehydrogenation reactions. Recent investigations into various metal-based catalysts including mono- and bi-metallic alloys and oxides have displayed promising performances due to their unique properties. This paper provides the comprehensive review and critical analysis of advancements in the CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes (C2-C4) on metal-based catalysts developed in recent years. Moreover, it offers a comparative summary of the structural properties, catalytic activities, and reaction mechanisms over various active sites, providing valuable insights for the future design of dehydrogenation catalysts. Graphical Abstract This review provides a critical analysis of the recent advances in CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes (C2–C4) over various metal-based catalysts. It aims to establish the structure-activity relationship which contributes to the oriented designing of dehydrogenation catalysts. Keywords Light alkanes dehydrogenation CO2 utilization Metal-based catalysts Light olefins Coupling reaction 1 Introduction Light olefins, including ethylene, propylene, and butylene, serve as the vital platform chemicals in manufacturing a diverse range of value-added products (alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids, oxygenates, polymers, etc.) in the chemical industry (Fig. 1 ) [1,2]. Those products find application across various industries, including packing, transportation, construction, food industry, electronic, and others. With the rapid development of global economy, the olefins demand continues to increase. The global olefins market exceeded 240 billion USD in 2022 and is expected to reach 348 billion USD by 2030 [3]. In 2023, the ethylene output of China reached 31.9 million tons, marking a 47.7% increase from the 21.6 million tons recorded in 2020 [4]. The diversification of raw materials, driven by varying resource endowments across different regions worldwide, has spurred the development of various olefin production processes [5,6]. The traditional processes for olefins production rely on steam cracking (SC) and fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) of naphtha and heavy oil [7,8], while the production cannot satisfy the growing global demand. Meanwhile, the traditional processes face challenges of high energy consumption, low selectivity to desired olefins, and declining crude oil reserves. Alternatively, light olefins can be produced from non-petroleum resources, like natural gas and coal, via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (F-T) and methanol-to-olefins (MTO). In recent decades, the high-quality, efficient, and low-carbon energy of shale gas drives a worldwide energy revolution. The production of shale gas in the United States had reached nearly 790 billion m3 in 2021 [9]. As the third country to achieve commercial shale gas development, China produced more than 25 billion m3 of shale gas in 2023 [10]. Shale gas primarily consists of methane and other light alkanes, among which ethane, propane, and butane make up to 15% of the hydrocarbons, yet they are often underutilized. Consequently, there is growing interest in converting light alkanes into olefins through the direct or oxidative dehydrogenation process [11–13]. 2 Alkanes dehydrogenation process Currently, the direct dehydrogenation of alkanes to olefins (DDH) has been industrialized using Pt- and CrO x -based catalysts through the Oleflex and Catofin processes, respectively [14–16]. Compared with conventional SC and FCC processes, the DDH process presents high selectivity of target olefins. While the DDH reaction is a thermodynamically limited reaction with the highly endothermic property (Table 1 , Eq. (1)). As shown in Figs. 2(a) and 2(b) , increasing the reaction temperature and/or decreasing the partial pressure can achieve a high alkane conversion. Additionally, the equilibrium conversions of light alkanes depend on the carbon numbers and the degrees of branching, which present the trend as follows: C2 < C3 < n-C4 < i-C4 [17]. In order to obtain an ideal conversion, the DDH process always operates at a high temperature from 550 to 750 °C. Thus, the harsh operating conditions increase energy consumption, more importantly, the catalyst sintering accelerates and the side reactions like thermal cracking and coke formation increase. To address the drawbacks of coking and sintering, the continuous reaction-regeneration is required in industrial processes which greatly increases the cost of catalysts. Compared with alkane molecules composed by C‐H and C‐C bond, olefin molecules with C=C bond are prone to be adsorbed and activated on the surface of catalyst. The geometric effect suggests that C‐H bonds in alkanes are preferentially activated. However, the average binding energy of C‐C bonds in alkanes is 347 kJ mol‐1, lower than the 414 kJ mol‐1 of C‐H bonds. This implies selectively breaking C‐H bonds and suppressing the activation of C‐C bonds in alkanes is crucial when designing dehydrogenation catalysts [18]. Meanwhile, for address the negative effects of high temperature on catalysts, the strategies like reaction atmosphere regulation are proposed. Selective oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes with O2 (O2-ODH) is a promising alternative pathway for olefin production [6,19,20]. In contrast to the DDH process, the O2-ODH process is combined with the selective hydrogen combustion reaction, in which the co-feeding O2 directly consumes the H species released from the alkanes, shifting the overall reaction towards olefin production [21–23]. O2-ODH reaction is exothermic and not limited by thermodynamics, as shown in Table 1 (Eq. (2)). Thus, this process reduces external heat requirement (mild operation temperature ranges of 350 to 600 °C), minimizes coke formation, and improves catalyst lifetime. However, co-feeding O2 leads to a decrease in the selectivity of target olefins due to the overoxidation of hydrocarbon products. In addition, the O2-ODH process may face the great challenge in large-scale industrial applications due to the explosion risk associated with the redox atmosphere. To address the issues, an alternative approach by introducing soft oxidants of CO2 is proposed. Industrial emissions of CO2 have been considered as the primary contributor to global warming. Total global CO2 emissions in 2021 reached 34.9 GtCO2, which rebounded by 4.8% in comparison to that in 2020 [24]. The continuously increasing demand for petroleum oil and natural gas will further increase CO2 emissions, which can result in worse environmental problems, such as frequent adverse climate events, polar ice melting, ocean acidification, and droughts [25]. In 2020, China made a significant decision to pursue “Carbon peaking and carbon neutralization”, hence optimizing energy structure and promoting the sustainable development of chemical industry are necessary. Meanwhile, the development of CO2 capture, storage, and utilization technologies (CCSU) is indispensable and promising, which will help mitigate climate change and reduce industrial costs [26]. Recently, various chemicals have been synthesized via CO2 hydrogenation, including CO, formic acid, alcohols, olefins, and aromatics [27–29]. In the meantime, the utilization of CO2 as a soft oxidant holds promise for industrial applications, enabling not only the resourceful utilization of CO2 but also facilitating the more cost-effective synthesis of various chemicals [30,31]. Currently, researchers are keen on using CO2 as the soft oxidant in various heterogeneous reactions, such as oxidative coupling of methane, oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes and alkyl aromatics [32–34]. Oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes with CO2 (CO2-ODH) is an endothermic reaction (Table 1 Eq. (3)), where CO2 is consumed as a co-reactant in CO2-ODH (Figs. 2(c) and (d)). Note that the endothermicity of CO2-ODH is greater than that of DDH, mainly contributed by the synergistic reaction of reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS, Table 1 Eq. (4)). Similar to the oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes using O2, the co-feeding of CO2 with mild oxidizing properties can alter the reaction pathway of direct dehydrogenation, or supply active species that participate in oxidative dehydrogenation. In former process, oxygen species in CO2 react with hydrogen species in alkanes to form H2O species, mitigating over-oxidation of alkanes and enhancing selectivity of on-purpose olefins. Generally, the CO2-ODH reactions typically follow the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism involving a redox cycle and the coupling reaction mechanism of DDH and RWGS [35]. In the case of the MvK mechanism, reactants undergo redox reactions over metal oxide catalysts having multiple oxidation states (such as CrO x , CeO x , ZrO x , etc.). The lattice oxygen species in metal oxides can activate and cleave the C‐H bond in alkanes, which are released by the formation of H2O. As a result, oxygen vacancies are generated that play the key role in activating the C=O bond in CO2, meanwhile, the active oxygen species are replenished which proceed to the next redox cycle. As for the coupling reaction mechanism, olefin and H2 are generated by the DDH reaction, subsequently the H2 is consumed by the RWGS reaction, which benefits for the shift of reaction towards olefin generation. The coupling reaction mechanism requires bifunctional catalysts with synergistic acidic-basic sites [36], the acidic sites dominate for activating the alkanes while the basic sites activate CO2. Furthermore, two distinct routes may occur on the same catalyst, which depends on the physicochemical properties of catalysts and the specific operation conditions. Nowicka et al. [37] proposed the MvK mechanism can be coupled with the RWGS reaction through the dual effect of CO2, which regenerates the active oxygen species while consumes H2 species. Therefore, recent studies have developed various metal-based catalysts and revealed the significant facilitation of CO2 on the activity and/or selectivity of dehydrogenation reactions through well-designed experiments. With regard to different types of catalysts, CO2 plays distinct promotional roles in CO2-ODH reactions, which can be summarized as follows (Fig. 3 ). (1) Consuming the hydrogen species derived from DDH reaction via reverse water-gas-shift (RWGS) reaction that shifts the equilibrium of DDH reaction. (2) Replenishing active oxygen species consumed by ODH reaction to refill oxygen vacancies based on the MvK mechanism. (3) Eliminating coke deposits on the surface of active metal sites through the reverse Boudouard reaction, thereby regenerating active sites. (4) Oxidizing the reduced metal sites that facilitates the cleavage of C‐C bonds to suppress side reactions. On the other hand, the presence of CO2 complicates the whole reaction network compared to DDH systems, leading to the slower industrialization of CO2-ODH. Unlike the simple product distribution in DDH reactions, the exhaust gas of CO2-ODH contains various products (olefins, CO, water, etc.) and unreacted reactants, significantly increasing the cost for separation and integrated utilization. Meanwhile, the energy consumption of CO2-ODH is higher than that of DDH (Table 1) due to endothermic RWGS reaction. Catalyst deactivation is dominantly derived from coke, and the ability of CO2 in CO2-ODH to remove coke is inadequate, especially for graphitized coke. Moreover, the additive CO2 would competitively adsorb on metal sites, weakening the activation of C‐H bonds in alkanes. Although the equilibrium conversion of CO2-ODH can be improved at a high reaction temperature, a parallel competitive reaction of dry-reforming of alkanes and CO2 also occurs (DRE, Table 1 Eq. (6)), as shown in Figs. 2(c), 2(e), and 2(f), the equilibrium conversion of DRE reaction is higher than that of CO2-ODH [38]. Therefore, catalyst design should consider the co-activation of the C‐H and C=O bonds, while also avoiding the cleavage of C‐C bond on the active sites [39]. On basis of the literatures in recent years, this review aims to provide a comprehensive account of catalyst advancements in CO2-assisted light alkanes (C2‐C4) dehydrogenation reactions, which involves the noble metal, transition metal oxide, bimetallic, and other catalysts. Additionally, we will also discuss the mechanism of CO2 activation and provide insights into the development trends and challenges of CO2-ODH technology. 3 Catalysts In recent decades, various catalysts have been developed for the oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes with CO2, including noble metals (Au, Pt, Pd, etc.) and metal oxides (Cr, Fe, Zn, etc.) (Fig. 4 ) [40,41]. Except for the bulk catalysts, active metals are also anchored on the surface or within the channels of porous materials, like Al2O3, CeO2, SBA-15, and Silicalite-1 (S-1), providing a high surface area to expose more active sites. For the CO2-ODH catalysts, the ability of CO2 activation should also be considered except for the selective cleavage of C-H bond [42,43]. Alkanes are mainly adsorbed on the acidic sites, while acidic CO2 prefers to adsorb on the basic sites. Therefore, ensuring appropriate acidic-basic properties of catalysts is crucial for synergistic activation of alkanes and CO2. 3.1 CO2-assisted ethane dehydrogenation reactions 3.1.1 Noble metal-based catalysts Noble metals are widely adopted as active components in the ethane dehydrogenation reaction due to their exceptional ability in activating C‐H bonds, along with excellent chemical and thermal stability. Meanwhile, in CO2-assisted ethane dehydrogenation (CO2-ODHE) reaction, there is a keen interest in constructing bifunctional sites through the combination of noble metal with reducible support and/or promoters, achieving the co-activation of light alkanes and CO2. Ceria is favored as a support material in the CO2-ODHE reaction because of its efficient oxygen storage and release properties. Xie et al. [44] prepared monometallic Pd supported on CeO2 by incipient wetness impregnation, and revealed the positive effects of active oxygen species at the Pd-CeO2 interface (Fig. 5(a) ). However, electron-deficient oxygen species on the Pd surface promote the non-selective scission of C‐C and C=C bonds to produce syngas. The density functional theory (DFT) calculation results showed the optimal activation energies for the C‐H and C‐C bonds in ethane are 144.09 and 29.58 kJ mol‐1, respectively [45]. This means that Pd-based catalysts are advantageous for producing syngas via dry-reforming reactions when CO2 and ethane are co-fed. Jalid et al. [46,47] assessed the bimetallic alloy and monometallic catalysts in CO2-ODHE reaction by in silico mean field microkinetic model. On the step (111) sites of monometallic catalysts, significant activity for CO2 conversion along with oxygen assisted ethane dehydrogenation were observed, which are higher than that on terrace (111) sites due to the high hydrogenolysis activity of the step surface. While compared with monometallic catalysts, alloying metals enhance the CO2 conversion. As bimetallic (PdMx )-derived catalysts (M = Ga, Sn, Fe, Ag, Au, Cu, Ni, Pt, Rh, Ru and Ir), two types of catalyst structures were identified under the CO2-ODHE reaction conditions (Fig. 5(b)): the PdCo x alloy surface favoring the formation of ethoxy which is a critical precursor for further C‐C bond scission, and the reaction-induced InO x /Pd interface promoting C‐H bond scission [48]. Meanwhile, formation energy of the PdMx surfaces and their binding energy to oxygen, which were proposed as the general descriptors of CO2-ODHE. The binding energy of bimetallic and O* derived from CO2 should be strong enough to drive the segregation of M to the surface in the form of MO x , which may facilitate the dissociation of C‐H bond for ethylene production. Otherwise, the stable surface of alloy can cleave C-C bond to produce syngas. In bimetallic PdFe catalyst, the interface oxygen species was effectively modified [44]. Due to the Kirkendall effect, the electron-enriched oxygen species on FeO x -Pd interface contribute to the generation of ethylene via boosting the C‐H bond scission and the ethylene desorption. Although the FeO x -CeO2 interface is not the dominant active site for CO2 or ethane activation, it exhibits strong interfacial Fe‐O‐Ce bonding, which confines the metal ensembles as well as decreases the supplement of non-selective oxygen species through weakening the reducibility of CeO2. Li et al. [49] also discovered the oxygen species derived from Pd1-Fe6/CeO2 in CO2-ODHE contributed to a stable ethylene selectivity of 80.4%. In comparison to Fe6/CeO2 catalyst, the oxygen species in Pd1-Fe6/CeO2 can decrease the energy barriers of ethylene formation and CO2 activation while increase the energy barrier of ethylene deep dehydrogenation by the DFT results. For recognizing the crucial role of surface oxygen species, Lei et al. [50] investigated Au species supported on CeO2 with different morphologies (nanorod and nanoparticle). H2-TPR analysis indicated the strong interaction between Au and CeO2 decreases the reduction temperature of pristine CeO2, prompting abundant oxygen species to migrate to the less stable (001) and (110) crystal planes. Correspondingly, the introduction of CO2 can sustainably replenish the consumed oxygen species on the CeO2 surface, and eliminate the carbonaceous deposits through the reverse Boudouard reaction. And the nanorod CeO2 supported Au exhibited ca. 17% ethylene yield (17% conversion and 98% selectivity) and well stability in CO2-ODHE reaction. Moreover, the modification of CeO2 by doped-metal (yttrium) can further enhance the CO2-ODHE activity via the improvement of the surface oxygen reductivity, the optimal Au/Ce0.9Y0.1 catalyst showed stable performance of 20.9% conversion and near 100% selectivity for 50 h [51]. In the case of Cs-doped Ru/CeO2, Cs species promote the dispersion of Ru species. Besides, the CeO2 support plays an important role in CO2-ODHE. During the CO2-ODHE reaction, the redox cycle between Ce3+ and Ce4+ facilitates the activation of CO2 and the removal of coke, which greatly improves the catalytic activity and stability (kept stable for 3 months) [52]. In addition to being a support, Ce species can act as the promoter of noble metal. In Numan's work, the as-prepared catalyst contains Pt5Ce intermetallic nanoparticles and single atomic Ce species after H2 reduction at 973 K [53]. DFT analysis indicated the monometallic Pt(111) is energetically favorable for CO formation via the dry-reforming reaction, contrasting with the case of bimetallic Pt5Ce. The introduction of Ce obviously weakens the affinity of ethylene on the surface of Pt, and inhibits excessive ethylene cleavage. Additionally, the single atomic Ce species closed to Pt5Ce intermetallic nanoparticles benefit for the activation of CO2 and the increase of the energy barrier of C-C bond scission, thereby suppressing the formation of CO via dry-reforming. Furthermore, the effect of second metal M (M = La, Y, Sc) on the Pt/zeolite nanosponge (ZNS) was also investigated [54]. In comparison to Pt@ZNS catalyst, co-impregnation with M can improve the dispersion of intermetallic nanoparticles, boosting the ethylene yield. The presence of LaO x in catalyst promotes the activation of CO2, facilitating the elimination of coke through the reverse Boudouard reaction. Conventional thermocatalytic dehydrogenation of ethane requires a large amount of heat due to its endothermic properties, thus the operation temperature should be higher than 873 K for desired olefins yield. Therefore, the development of more cost-effective catalytic processes, such as the introduction of extra energy, has been considered by researchers. Wang et al. [55] compared the effect of microwave and conventional heat mode on the CO2-ODHE reaction over CsRu/CeO2. Microwave heating lowers the reaction temperature by 150‐200 °C versus the conventional heating process, while maintains the comparable ethane conversion and ethylene yield. The advantage of microwave heating likely stems from its selective heating of active sites. At the catalyst-reactants interface, microwave may cause electron or ion discharge, resulting in surface polarization and activation energy decrease. The low temperature by microwave heat benefits the decrease of coke deposits that improves the catalytic stability [56]. In addition, Zhang et al. [57] presented a novel strategy for the photocatalytic dehydrogenation of ethane using CO2 over Pd/TiO2 catalyst under the mild conditions. After the screening test, the optimal 1% Pd/TiO2 produced highest yields of ethylene and syngas of 230.5 and 282.6 μmol h‐1 g‐1, respectively. DFT analysis showed that the middle energy level and electron channel of Pd/TiO2 promote electron transfer, excitation and separation. 3.1.2 Cr-based catalysts Chromium-based catalysts, which have been widely studied in direct dehydrogenation and utilized in the industrial Catofin process. On account of its multiple oxidation states, the redox cycle between the high and low chemical valencies of chromium oxides is promoted. Thus, Cr-based catalysts become one of the earliest catalysts used for oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes with soft oxidants. Generally, the dehydrogenation activities of Cr-based catalysts are strongly dependent on the state of chromium species and the support materials. Three types of oxides are clearly revealed for the supported CrO x , i.e. isolated Cr6+, polymeric Cr6+ and crystalline Cr2O3 (Fig. 6(a) ) [58,59]. Crystalline Cr2O3 species are inactive during the CO2-ODH reaction, which can be formed by increasing the chromium loading [60]. Thus, increasing the amount and dispersion of Cr6+ species is crucial for enhancing dehydrogenation activity (Figs. 6(b)‐(f)). The dispersion of CrO x species relies on the texture properties of supports. For instance, the relatively larger pore size of 6.8 nm facilitates the embedding of the isolated Cr6+ species into the framework of SBA-15, while the inactive Cr3+ species mainly accumulate on the surface of SBA-15 [63]. This improves the reducibility and basicity of the catalyst, which plays the key role in activating the C-H bond in ethane and C=O bond in CO2. Differing from the aggregated CrO x species on SBA-15, single-site chromium species were formed on the surface of all-silica MFI zeolite (S-1). The excellent stability of single-site Cr species can be attributed to the presence of framework defects in S-1, the geometric isolation effect, and the strong interaction with the S-1 surface [67]. Additionally, Cr-supported hydrophilic zeolite exhibited better activity than hydrophobic zeolite (44% vs. 25%) at similar ethylene selectivity [68]. Cheng et al. [64] compared the CO2-ODHE activities of CrO x supported ZSM-5 catalysts with different crystallite sizes (nanometer, submicron and micrometer), and the results revealed that the activity mainly correlates with the silanol groups on the support surface rather than the crystallite sizes. Silanol nests play a more important role in the dispersion of Cr6+ species than the terminal silanol groups, which determines the dehydrogenation activity. Increasing the framework Si/Al ratios by in-situ synthesis or dealumination can increase the amount of silanol groups [69,70]. While a high temperature calcination can decrease the number of surface silanol, which results in the aggregation of CrO x species in the subsequent impregnation. While it can be recovered by rehydroxylation with diluted H2O2 [65]. Additionally, compared with the catalysts prepared by impregnation and one-step hydrothermal synthesis with the sequence of TEOS then Cr, Al-Awadi et al. [66] discovered the catalyst prepared by one-step hydrothermal synthesis with the sequence of Cr then TEOS exhibited the highest ethane conversion (~58%) and ethylene yield (53%). The pre-added chromium species decreases the pH values of solution, which favors to the formation of mesoporous silica nanoparticles with small particle size and large pore size, benefiting for the dispersion of CrO x species. Although mesoporous silicon can promote the dispersion of Cr6+ species, the sintering of metals is inevitable during the CO2-ODH process [67]. The redox cycle between Cr6+ and Cr3+ is crucial in CO2-ODHE reactions. Generally, it is difficult that CO2 oxidizes Cr3+ to Cr6+ due to its weak oxidizability. However, Franceschini et al. [71] considered that the oxidation of Cr3+ by CO2 depends on the reaction temperature. At the high reaction temperatures, ethane is converted to ethylene mainly through the direct dehydrogenation reaction, and the key role of CO2 is eliminating coke deposits. While at low reaction temperatures, CO2 promotes the re-oxidation of Cr3+ to Cr6+ that favors the oxidative dehydrogenation reactions. As for aggregated Cr2O3 nanoparticles, the Cr3+ hardly can be oxidized to Cr6+ by CO2. The addition of O2 can further enhance the catalyst stability by facilitating the redispersion of sintered Cr2O3 nanoparticles, forming isolated Cr6+ species [72]. The state of Cr species also can be adjusted by interacting with other metal species. For instance, the introduction of potassium could enhance the basicity of Cr/CeZrO x , it promotes CO2 activation and ethylene desorption for achieving a stable CO2-ODHE activity [73]. However, excessive potassium introduction facilitates the generation of some difficult-to-reduce K2CrO4/K2Cr2O7 species which cover the oxygen vacancy, resulting in the decrease of catalytic activity. Additionally, Ce- and Zr-modification of catalysts contribute to the improvement of oxygen storage capacity, the increase of active oxygen content, the regulation of acidity-basicity, and the balance of coke formation and gasification rates. Meanwhile, the dispersion of Cr6+ species has been improved by strengthening the interaction between supports and chromium species [74–76]. Thus, the optimal 5%Cr-10%Ce/ZSM-5 maintained the initial CO2-ODHE activity (64% ethane conversion, 80% ethylene selectivity) for 30 h at 800 °C [77]. Bugrova et al. [62] found that the pathway and activity of the ethane-CO2 reaction depend on the physicochemical properties of supports, which are the key to achieve the reoxidation of chromium species. For example, the reaction mechanism over CrO x /Al2O3 mainly follows the coupling reactions of direct dehydrogenation and RWGS. Meanwhile, the catalyst deactivation is mainly caused by the side reactions over the acidic Al sites, and the few basic sites suppress the adsorption and activation of CO2. As for CrO x /ZrO2, ethylene is produced from the oxidative dehydrogenation route following the MvK mechanism, accompanied by the side reactions of dry-reforming and/or non-selective oxidation. Its rapid deactivation can be assigned to the sintering of metal sites and the formation of inactive CrO x species. 3.1.3 Fe-based catalysts Given the scarcity of noble metals and environmental concerns related to Cr species, alternative catalysts employing transition metals (Fe, Zn, Co, Ga, etc.) as active centers for CO2-ODH have been developed. Among those catalysts, the Fe-based catalysts have been commercialized for the ethylbenzene dehydrogenation [78]. However, they exhibit poor activity for alkanes dehydrogenation, which could be explained by the reduction of supported FeO x nanoparticle followed by carbonization to FeC x [79]. Indeed, iron species generally exhibit multiple oxidation states under alkane dehydrogenation reaction conditions. Gascon et al. [80] claimed the in situ formed metallic Fe species result in the deep cracking of alkanes and coke formation, while the stable Fe2+ species contribute to the stable and selective ethane dehydrogenation performance. Yang et al. [81] incorporated isolated Fe δ+ sites into S-1 framework to suppress their reduction and carbonization, the optimal catalyst achieved a stable high ethane conversion (26.3%) and ethylene selectivity (97.5%) in 200 h of ethane dehydrogenation reaction. Zheng et al. [82] discovered that the Fe3+ active sites can atomically disperse on the surface of MgAl2O4 spinel via a simple impregnation, and the evolution of Fe species during ethane dehydrogenation with/without CO2 reaction was revealed. The isolated Fe3+ species undergo reduction, sintering, detachment and carbonization during the direct dehydrogenation process (Fig. 7 ). CO2 co-feeding effectively stabilizes the isolated iron species, while the inevitable reduction from octahedral Fe3+ to tetrahedral Fe2+ results in the gradually decreased activity owing to the mild oxidation of CO2. The activity can be restored for 6 cycles by regenerating atomically dispersed Fe3+ species with air. The deactivation evolution of Fe species in direct dehydrogenation can be ascribed to the weak interaction of metal and support. Thus, they further doped iron species into ZrO2 lattice to strengthen the interaction, and investigated the performance in CO2-ODHE reaction [83]. Fe-doping induces the transformation of monoclinic ZrO2 to metastable tetragonal ZrO2, creating more active oxygen species that greatly increases the ethane conversions. Three distinct reaction periods of CO2-ODHE were observed over the Fe-doped ZrO2 catalyst, which correlates with the evolution of active oxygen species following the MvK mechanism. Although CO2 co-feeding enhances the catalytic stability by supplementing active oxygen species, gradual deposition of graphitic coke prevents the supplementation of oxygen species, leading to catalyst deactivation due to the weak oxidation of CO2. Air-regeneration can restore the catalytic performance of the Fe-doped ZrO2 catalyst. Considering the relative low activity of Fe-based catalysts, researchers introduced other metals (like Ni, Co [84], Pd [44]) for enhancing their activity in CO2-ODHE reactions. Lemonidou’ group prepared Fe-supported catalysts using Ni-modified MgO-ZrO2 as support, which boosts the CO2-ODHE activity, and is twice that of Fe/MgO-ZrO2 [85–87]. With the doping of nickel species in a solid solution with MgO, the deposited FeO x are strongly interacted with those nickel species [85]. DFT results demonstrated that the improved activity arises from the reduced oxygen vacancy formation energy and increases hydrogen adsorption energy on the interface of Ni-FeO x . Moreover, the interface serves as the potential active site for selective scission of C‐H bond rather than C‐C bond, which can be tuned by changing the Ni/Fe ratios [86]. The initial rapid deactivation due to metal sintering can be mitigated by surface iron enrichment over time, leading to sustained activity [85]. In addition, XAS and pyridine-adsorption FTIR spectroscopy verified that prolonged high-temperature calcination induces iron species dope into the lattice of support, altering the geometric structure of magnesium species. This process enhances the acidity of catalyst while reduces basic oxygen species [87]. Meanwhile, the transformation of magnesium coordination from octahedral to tetrahedral obviously enhances the ethylene selectivity. Depending on the oxidizability of CO2 and O2, the ethylene yield can be restored to 76% and 100%, respectively, after regenerating spent catalysts. Jalid et al. [47] found Ni3Fe displays highest potential among three alloy candidates (Ni3Fe, Ni3Co and Pt3Co), as it lies at the top of the volcano curve for CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane, which was evidenced by the FeNi/CeO2 catalysts from Chen's group [88]. Meanwhile, Chen and co-workers proposed that the ideal oxidative dehydrogenation catalyst should consist of the reducible oxides as support and the optimum active metal loading. The active sites response to selective scission of C‐H bonds to produce olefins, and the support directly activates CO2 by breaking the C=O bond [89]. As confirmed in the FeNi/CeO2, the Ni-FeO x interface and Ni-CeO x interface are verified as the active sites for CO2-assisted dehydrogenation and dry-reforming reactions, respectively [90], both of them are facilitated by the surface active oxygen species [91]. When nickel and iron species co-load on CeO2, the Ni-FeO x interface is preferentially formed than the Ni-CeO x interface. Specifically, both iron and nickel species on CeO2 are transformed to Ni-rich NiFe alloy and crystalline ferric oxides during the reaction, and the iron species in NiFe alloy are transformed to amorphous FeO x thin layer via re-oxidization by CO2. The FeO x overlayer, as the oxygen supply buffer, provides weakly electrophilic oxygen species to proceed the formation of ethylene. While the strongly electrophilic oxygen species from the CeO2 could participate in the production of CO. In addition, excessive loading amount of FeNi would alter dehydrogenation to dry-reforming, because the FeO x species on the perimeter of nickel particles are likely reduced [89]. Similar to Ni-FeO x interface, the Pd-FeO x interface promotes the selective cleavage of C‐H bonds and ethylene desorption in CO2-ODHE reactions [49], owing to the limitation of non-selective oxygen supply by the FeO x -CeO2 interface [44]. On basis of the above discussion, irreducible SiO2 and ZrO2 are unsuitable as the support for FeNi catalyzes CO2-ODHE reaction as they often lead to the occurrence of reforming reactions [89]. Li et al. [92] prepared different crystalline ZrO2 (monoclinic, tetragonal and mixed) and revealed that the various crystal faces had different binding abilities to the O* species and the active site of FeNi. Monoclinic ZrO2 selectively exposes the (‐111) and (111) surfaces with more oxygen vacancies, strengthening the interaction between metal and support, which facilitates the formation of the highly active Fe x Zr1‐x O2 structure for oxidative dehydrogenation. The oxygen vacancies and Fe2+-O-Zr3+ site can activate CO2 to replenish O* via the scission of C=O bond, then the O* species on Fe3+-O-Zr4+ sites are captured and reacted with H* to form H2O. Except for the energy-saving processes like microwave heating and photocatalysis discussed earlier, Zhang et al. [93] proposed a sustainable catalytic approach for CO2-ODHE reaction: photothermal catalysis that integrates photochemical and thermocatalytic processes into one unit. Experiments and simulations revealed the visible light and UV-light are responsible for oxidative dehydrogenation and non-oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane to ethylene, respectively. Compared to monometallic catalyst under light irradiation, carbon nanotubes confining FeNi bimetallic alloy can generate more internal heat and energetic hot carriers, which benefited the dissociation of C=O and C‐H bonds. 3.1.4 Co-based catalysts In comparison to Fe-based catalysts, cobalt-based materials have attracted much attention due to the high activity in the activation of C‐H bond and high olefins selectivity. However, the Co3O4 nanoparticles are easy to be reduced and aggregated into Co0 particles that promote coke formation via the C‐C bond cleavage. This results in a decrease of active sites and rapid deactivation [94–96]. Meanwhile, cobalt particles could facilitate the dry-reforming reactions when co-fed with CO2 [88,97]. Zheng et al. [97] delved into the impact of CO2 introduction on the nanostructure of cobalt species and corresponding dehydrogenation performances (Fig. 8 ). Different catalytic performances, including dehydrogenation and dry-reforming reaction, are observed over Co/S-1 contained CoO x nanocluster and Co3O4 nanoparticle when employing in CO2-ODHE reactions with different feeding CO2/C2H6 ratios. The reduction, sintering and coke deposition happens over cobalt species during the ethane direct dehydrogenation. The introduction of moderate amounts of CO2 can effectively stabilize active Co2+ site while simultaneously passivate metallic cobalt nanoparticles. This led to a stable dehydrogenation performance with ethylene selectivity higher than 95% for 120 h. Excessive CO2 introduction causes the transformation of deactivated metallic cobalt particles to reforming reaction sites that can activate C‐C and C=O bonds. Thus dry-reforming dominates in the reaction and more syngas is produced. Similarly, Liu et al. [98,99] proposed subnanometric CoO clusters benefit for the selective scission of C‐H bonds in alkanes. But there is still controversy regarding the active cobalt species for the direct dehydrogenation (Fig. 9 ), more reports favor the active centers of isolated tetrahedral Co2+ species [94,100–107]. In addition, highly dispersed ultrasmall Co0 particles and unsaturated Co species are also proposed as the active centers [108,109]. Yu et al. [110] recently reported that tri-coordinated single-atom cobalt in zeolite exhibited higher olefins yield than tetrahedral Co2+ species. However, the investigation of cobalt species catalyzing CO2-ODH reactions are relative less than DDH. For instance, the activities of Co/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by impregnation (IM) and ion-exchange (IE) are compared in the ethane-CO2 conversion reaction [111]. Due to the different states of cobalt species, dry-reforming reaction dominantly occurs on CoZ-IM, while CoZ-IE catalyzes the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethylene with an ethylene selectivity higher than 95%. Characterization results indicated that the cobalt species in CoZ-IE individually anchored within the zeolite framework act as the Lewis acidic sites for dehydrogenation. While the mixed oxides particles (Co2+ and Co3+) in CoZ-IM follow redox cycles. Koirala et al. [112] revealed the structural and catalytic activity of Co/SiO2 with the different cobalt amount for CO2-ODHE. At a cobalt loading lower than 1.0 wt%, the highly dispersed tetrahedral Co2+ in cobalt silicate are dominated that benefits for dehydrogenation reactions. While CoO x clusters are dominated at a high cobalt loading that favors the formation of coke. Meanwhile, XAS analysis evidenced the presence of H2O facilitates the transformation of tetrahedral Co2+ into octahedral Co2+ during the reaction, resulting in decreased ethylene selectivity [113,114]. It has reported that the highly dispersed Co cations stabilized in the framework of zeolite exhibit excellent dehydrogenation activity. Guo et al. [115] pointed out that not all the highly dispersed Co cations are active for the dehydrogenation and only those located in the internal channels contribute to dehydrogenation activity. CO2 is in charge of the elimination of coke via reverse Boudouard reaction rather than the consumption of H2. In the case of Co-based bimetallic catalysts [84,88,116–118], the Co-based alloys significantly reduce the coke formation rates, thus both of activity and stability are enhanced in comparison to monometallic catalysts [46]. Yao et al. [118] reported that cobalt cations can be inserted into MoO x domains and the CoMoO x moieties are created which could effectively activate CO2. The kinetically relevant activation of C–H bond should be assisted by active oxygen species that generated from the activation of CO2 following RWGS reaction. Meanwhile, the CO2 activation rate also determines the reaction rates of dehydrogenation and dry-reforming. 3.1.5 Other metal-based catalysts Molybdenum-based catalysts have been reported to be a possible potential candidate for activating C–H bond in alkanes and C=O bond in CO2, but it exhibits relatively poor stability in CO2-ODHE reaction [119–121]. In Marquart's work, a series of Mo2C-supported catalysts exhibited rapid decrease in activity with time on stream due to the shift from dry-reforming to dehydrogenation [122]. In addition, β-Mo2C species favors the activation of CO2, while MoO x C y species facilitate the scission of C–H bond in ethane followed MvK mechanism. The oxidation of Mo2C species induce the catalysts deactivation, while increasing reaction temperature can limit the oxidation process due to the carburization by ethane [123]. But the coke formed by the depleted active oxygen species on catalyst surface still result in the deactivation. Active oxygen species benefit the CO2 activation, surface oxidation of oxyphilic carbides proceeds rapidly in presence of CO2. While surface reduction proceeds more slowly, which is limited by the removal of oxygen species from the catalyst surface [124]. The oxygen species in molybdenum species can be created via iron doping though the initial activity decreases [125]. Yao et al. [126] also discovered that modification the surface of Mo2C by oxygen species is vital for suppressing C–C bond scission and increasing ethene yield. Meanwhile, iron promoter accelerates the generation of MoO x layer and suppresses the coke deposition. While cobalt species prefer to activate the oxygen species in CO2, enhancing the rate of the RWGS reaction [118]. Unlike the promoting effect of iron and cobalt species, potassium species remove the oxygen species as well as acidic sites, thereby restricting ethane activation. Nickel species, on the other hand, accelerate the activation of C=O bond for dry-reforming, whereas platinum species result in cracking reactions via C–C bond scission [125]. In addition, as for MoO x /CeO2-TiO2 catalysts, the surface MoO x species anchored on TiO2 prefer to the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane via MvK mechanism, while the pure support benefits the direct dehydrogenation of ethane [127]. Although CeO2 introduction enhanced the redox ability of catalysts, the irreversible loss of oxygen species in MoO x leads to catalyst deactivation during dehydrogenation reaction. Bikbaeva et al. [128] reported a novel synthesis route for Mo2C: the “sulfide” route, wherein the precursor MoS2 underwent in situ transformation on a non-acidic embryonic zeolite, preventing the sintering of Mo species during the carbide formation. The as-prepared catalyst presented a high CO2-ODHE activity (66% ethane conversion) than that of the “oxide” route. Vanadium-based materials are active for the CO2-ODHE reaction, and the performance depends on the interaction of V species with supports. Taghavinezhad et al. [129] prepared V-based catalyst using MgO-ZrO2 mixed oxides as the support. The addition of MgO induces the transformation of monoclinic ZrO2 to tetragonal ZrO2, which inhibits the aggregation of vanadium species and reduces the particle sizes. Consequently, the CO2-ODHE activities of those catalysts are improved than that of VO x /MgO or VO x /ZrO2. The optimal catalyst with Mg/Zr ratios of 3 exhibited a stable activity for 10 h with highest the ethylene yield of 60%. Furthermore, they pretreated VO x /MgO-ZrO2 with various molarities of H2SO4 solution (0, 0.5, 1 and 2) [130]. Characterization results unraveled a correlation between activity and the sulfur content on the support, as the molarity of H2SO4 influences the crystallinity of tetragonal ZrO2, thereby altering the state of V species. In addition, MgO- and ZrO2-modified MCM-41 zeolites facilitates the formation of oligomeric tetrahedral vanadium species, which promotes the selective scission of C‐H bond in ethane [131]. Based on characterization results, it is speculated that VO x -based catalyst follows the MvK mechanism, wherein CO2 plays a crucial role in the reoxidation of reduced VO x species for achieving the stable activity. Since gallium oxide supported on ZSM-5 was firstly employed in the light alkanes dehydrogenation reaction in 1980s [132], Ga-based catalysts have been widely studied in dehydrogenation field, including CO2-ODHE [56,133,134]. The coordinatively unsaturated Ga3+ species with medium-strong acidic sites generally existed in β-Ga2O3, which showed the highest activity among four different gallium oxide polymorphs [135]. Xie et al. [136] reported the CO2-ODHE activities of Ga-doped MgAl2O4 catalysts are correlated with the coordinatively unsaturated Ga3+ species, which correspond to the number of medium-strong acidic sites. The metal dispersion effect of silanol mentioned in section 3.1.1 is also applied to gallium-supported catalysts, the improved dispersion of gallium species generates lots of Lewis acidic sites which benefit for the activation of ethane [137]. Meanwhile, enhanced interaction of silanol nests with gallium species increases the acidity of Brønsted acidic site, thus the dehydrogenation reaction is promoted. By comparing bulk TiO2 with mesoporous TiO2, the latter supported gallium species exhibited a higher CO2-ODHE activity. This is also attributed to its higher specific surface area, which facilitates the effective dispersion of gallium species [138]. While Ga/TiO2 exhibits low ethylene selectivity in CO2-ODHE reaction due to the large acidic site density, Si-modified TiO2 can weaken the interaction between TiO2 with gallium species and decrease the acidic site density, leading to the enhancement of ethylene selectivity and catalyst stability [139]. Coupling RWGS and ethane dehydrogenation reactions can be observed over zinc-based catalysts [140]. The highly dispersed zinc sites on SSZ-13 exhibited high ethane and CO2 conversions and high ethylene selectivity [141]. This can be attributed to the unique channel structure of SSZ-13 for CO2 conversion [142]. Neutralizing the catalyst acidity with K2O further enhances activity by reducing the energy barrier for product adsorption and inhibiting CH4 formation via hydrogenolysis. In addition, the effect of steam and CO2 on ethane activation over Zn-ZSM-5 was explored [143]. The FTIR spectroscopic analysis revealed that ethylene prefers to adsorb on the Lewis acidic site of Zn rather than the Brønsted acidic site (BAS), while water hydrolyzes the Zn sites and forms Zn(OH)+ and a new BAS, but oligomerization/aromatization reactions are suppressed though the BAS is generated. In addition, Li et al. [144] discovered that the ceria-based catalysts for dry-reforming can be transformed to a selectively dehydrogenation catalyst after coating a SiO2 layer. High-sensitivity low-energy ion scattering spectroscopy and DFT results indicated that the Si-O-Ce interfacial sites effectively restrict the deep oxidation and promote the release of ethylene. The reaction parameters for the metal-based catalysts in CO2-ODHE are shown in Table 2 and Fig. 4(a), including feed composition, temperature, space velocity, conversion and selectivity. Considering the chemical stability of ethane molecules, reaction temperatures above 600 °C are generally required. Thermal stability of metal species is crucial in the CO2-ODHE. Additionally, the catalysts must possess bifunctional sites to activate both ethane and CO2. Increasing attention has been paid to bimetallic catalysts. To address these issues, the main approach currently involves modifying the structure and electronic properties of active metal species by introducing promoters or adjusting the physicochemical properties of supports. These modifications enhance the dispersion of active sites and create interface sites for synergistic activation of ethane and CO2. 3.2 CO2-assisted propane dehydrogenation reactions 3.2.1 Noble metal-based catalysts Pt-supported materials, as the commercially Oleflex process catalysts of propane direct dehydrogenation, are widely used in CO2-assisted propane dehydrogenation (CO2-ODHP) reactions [146]. In comparison with monometallic catalysts, the bimetallic catalysts show improved conversion and stability [147,148]. Monometallic Pt tends to preferentially activate C‐C bond in alkanes, while PtM-MO x interface plays a vital role in highly selective activation of alkanes and CO2 via introducing a second component, which can be attributed to the weakened interaction between the adsorbate and alloy surface. Kinetic studies revealed the CO2-ODHP reaction on Pt-M bimetallic catalysts follows a two-stage pathway: the dominant initial stage is the DDH reaction, followed by a coupling reaction between DDH and RWGS in the second stage, with the RWGS reaction limits the overall reaction kinetics [149]. Interestingly, when SiO2 is substituted with reductive CeO2 as the support, the redox reaction cycle shifts to follow the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism, which is facilitated by the replenishment of oxygen species through CO2 dissociation [150]. Additionally, in Pd/CeZrAlO x catalyst, researchers found that Pd enhanced the oxygen transfer capability of the CeZrAlO x support, allowing the MvK mechanism and RWGS reaction to be linked through a common step [37]. Recently, Ding et al. [149] reported that Pt-M (M = Sn, In, Zn) bimetallic catalysts could break the equilibrium limit of direct propane dehydrogenation via H2 consumption by RWGS reaction, and increasing the M/Pt ratios could increase the degree of alloying and Pt isolation. For instance, the increasing ratios of Sn/Pt improved the propylene selectivity while propane conversion decreased [150,151]. Besides of the dispersion effect of Sn species, the enhanced selectivity also owes to Sn-doping that improves the electron density of Pt, favoring the propane adsorption and C‐H bond scission. Sn species modified the Pt‐O‐Ce bond, which contributes to the release of active oxygen species in the Sn-modified Pt and CeO2 boundaries. In addition, the Pt@Sn core-shell structure in MWW zeolite was developed [152]. The incorporation of Sn makes the MWW framework unstable at high temperature. Sn species are extracted to form SnO2 within the “half-cup” supercage via the breakage of Sn‐O‐Si bonds, and Pt species are encapsulated in it. The SnO2 shell modifies the Pt active sites for suppressing the dissociation of C‐C bonds and the accumulation of coke, meanwhile, it immobilizes Pt clusters for improving anti-sintering, thus the dehydrogenation selectivity and stability were greatly enhanced. Moreover, the CO2-ODH reaction occurred on Pt@Sn/MWW follows the two-step coupling reaction (DDH + RWGS), the apparent activation energy of the reaction process decreases after the introduction of CO2, contributed by the low CO2 binding energy of Pt-Sn catalyst. In the case of coke formation site on bimetallic catalyst, Bian et al. [153] discovered the excessive FeO x on the PtFe/S-1 catalyst surface can be reduced to Fe0 nanoparticles facilitating the scission of C-C bond in propane. The co-feeding of CO2 in reaction oxidizes the Fe0 nanoparticles to Fe3O4 without destroying the active PtFe alloy surface, as a result, a stable dehydrogenation activity was obtained by significantly inhibiting the hydrogenolysis and coking reactions. Replacing Sn4+ cations with Zn2+ cations that results in the highly dispersed Pt active sites on the hierarchical S-1 nanosheets, forming ultra-small Pt-Zn alloy nanoparticles [154]. The synergistic effect between Pt and Zn is beneficial for the coupling reaction of DDH with RWGS, and PtZn alloy enhances the propylene yield through the consumption of H2 by RWGS reaction. DFT analysis indicated the adsorption energy of CO on Pt-Zn (110) is much lower than that of Pt (111), relating to the enhanced electron density of the Pt site after Zn doping. In addition, Yuan et al. [155] discovered that the incorporation of isolated Zn2+ sites into the finned S-1 framework not only effectively activates the C‐H bond in propane but also induces highly dispersed RhPt nanoparticles, which are favorable for the activation of CO2 (Fig. 10 ). Due to the synergistic electron and structure effects, the optimal 0.25%Rh0.50%Pt @Zn-MFI showed the best propylene yield, satisfactory CO2 conversion, and long-term stability. Similarly, the doping of cobalt species can prevent the growth of Pt nanoparticles and activate reactant molecules [156]. And the dealumination of H-beta zeolite endows abundant silanol group on the surface, serving as anchoring sites to promote the dispersion of PtCo species through metal-support interaction. However, the alloy nanoparticles of different Pt/Co ratios significantly tune the reaction pathways between CO2-ODHP and dry-reforming. The optimal Pt1Co1-SiBeta catalyst exhibits weak adsorption of propylene in C3H6-TPD, indicating that the deep cracking of C‐C bonds is suppressed, and the PtCo nanoparticles show anti-sintering properties, achieving stability during the reaction. In addition, Furukawa and co-workers [157] reported the Pt-Co-In ternary nanoalloy on CeO2 that has a (Pt1‐x Co x )2In3 pseudo-binary alloy structure. The doped cobalt species offer a high density of states derived from the cobalt 3d orbitals near the Fermi level, which increases the adsorption intensity of carbon and hydrogen species and facilitates the activation of propane and CO2. Meanwhile, alloying with indium species enhances the C3H6 selectivity due to the ensemble effect. The CO2-reduction capacity of ternary alloy and the oxygen-releasing ability of CeO2 enable the continuous self-regeneration function and remarkable anti-coking, which facilitate MvK-type coke combustion and result in high and stable activity of CO2-ODHP. Furthermore, they designed a high-entropy intermetallics (HEI) (PtCoNi)(SnInGa) nanoparticles supported on CeO2, which showed highly coke resistant and thermally stability for CO2-ODHP reaction [158]. The Pt and Sn sites of intermetallic PtSn are partially replaced by Co/Ni and In/Ga species, respectively. The doped Co/Ni species are favor to activating CO2 molecules, and diluting Pt-Pt sites for higher selectivity. Meanwhile, the doped In/Ga species can enhance the thermodynamic stability of catalyst via increasing mixing entropy. The higher number of constituent metals also enhance the kinetic stability of nanoparticles owing to the sluggish diffusion effect, which prevents sintering or segregation [159]. As in the RuCr bimetallic system, the CO2 and propane conversions are significantly increased, because the ability of CO2 hydrogenation to CO is improved [160]. 3.2.2 Cr-based catalysts In Cr-based catalysts, the CO2-ODH activity correlates well with the dispersion of Cr species and the initial content of high-dispersed Cr6+ species [161]. The silanol group on SiO2 surface can form the Cr species with different Cr‐O bond length: mono-, di- and polychromate (Cr6+) and also crystallites of Cr2O3 (Cr3+) [162]. Except for α-Cr2O3, the others show high catalytic activity in propane dehydrogenation. Noting that the coordinatively unsaturated Cr3+ species play a vital role in redox mechanism of CO2-ODH [163], which are generated from the reaction of propane with the O species of terminal Cr=O bonds in initial Cr6+ oxides [161]. The Cr species can be highly dispersed on S-1 in the forms of isolated and polymeric Cr6+ oxides due to the anchor effect of silanol nests [164]. The density of silanol nests, determined by S-1 crystal sizes (0.06‐0.35 μm), correlates with the structure and number of Cr6+ oxides, which affect the interaction of Cr species with support. Meanwhile, the high specific surface areas of SiO2 and carbon materials benefit the stabilization and dispersion of Cr6+ species, which promotes the contact of reactants with active Cr species. However, narrow pores restrict reactant diffusion, and graphitized carbon supports can enhance the anti-sintering ability of CrO x particles [162,165]. In addition, the acidity from Al sites in the Cr/Albeta catalyst is prone to the deep cracking of propane into light hydrocarbons [166]. Meanwhile, CO2 co-feeding suppresses the formation rate of propylene due to its strong adsorption in the form of carbonates. While the dealumination by HNO3 results in the obvious changes of acidic-basic property of beta zeolite, consequently enhancing the conversions and selectivity of CO2-ODHP over Cr/Sibeta catalysts. Compared to conventional impregnation, Daresibi et al. [167] employed the atomic layer deposition (ALD) to load CrO x on SiO2, and obtained a high content of high-dispersed polymeric Cr6+ species, resulting in improved specific reaction rates in CO2-ODHP. In addition, CrO x nanoparticles were encapsulated into the framework of TUD-1 by microwave irradiation, which improves the interaction of Cr species with support, inducing the inter-transition of Cr6+ and Cr3+/Cr2+ species. The optimal 7% Cr-TUD-1 showed relatively high and stable CO2-ODHP activity [168]. While the order of precursor addition is also crucial for the catalytic activity of Cr-doped mesoporous silica spheres, as well as for the dispersion of Cr species [169]. In comparison to Cr/MMS-1 (Cr followed by TEOS), Cr/MMS-2 (TEOS followed by Cr) exhibited better and more stable activity in CO2-ODHP, along with anti-coking properties, attributed to the higher dispersion of Cr and the highest proportion of medium acidic sites. Characterization results revealed that the sequence of Cr then TEOS would induce large amount of CrO x species being encapsulated by silica. And the active sites are hardly exposed to propane even after removing the surfactant. Besides of Si-based materials, the oxygen storage materials such as ZrO2 and CeO2 are selected to support Cr active site for CO2-ODHP [170–172]. Xie et al. [173] used acid-base pair pathway and evaporation-induced self-assembly method to synthesize Cr-doped ZrO2. Abundant isolated and oligomeric Cr6+ species highly disperses into the mesopore structure of ZrO2, inducing the crystalline phase transition of ZrO2. The characterization results revealed the main active site of CO2-ODHP is the coordinatively unsaturated isolated and oligomeric Cr3+ species with activated oxygen. Due to the strong adsorption of CO2 on CrO x active site, the initial propane conversion is lower than that of direct dehydrogenation [174]. The primary role of CO2 is to suppress coke formation rather than its removal, except for preventing the reduction of Cr3+ to Cr2+ [173]. Dou et al. [175] also revealed the Cr3+ species, rather than Cr6+ species, serve as the active sites for CO2-ODHP via non-oxidative dehydrogenation (Fig. 11 ). The dominant deactivation mechanism involves coke formation, which can be restored by air-regeneration. While introducing Ce into Cr/ZrO2 solid solution alters the electron structure of Cr3+ species, increasing the energy barrier of C‐C bond scission, which effectively suppresses the formation of light hydrocarbons and enhanced propylene selectivity (from 57% to 82%) and stability. In addition, the CO2-ODHP kinetic behavior of CrO x sites was studied [172]. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic model was developed to account for the dominant reaction pathways (DDH, RWGS and dry-reforming). Although increasing the loading of Cr species enhances the activity of dehydrogenation, the active sites are easier to be reduced, that results in significant occurrence of dry-reforming reaction. The total consumption rate of propane mainly depends on the partial pressure of propane, while the partial pressure of CO2 obviously affects the selectivity of propylene [176]. Although they deemed the activity of CrO x /Al2O3 lies on the activation of CO2 through the MvK mechanism, which is kinetically limited by the temperature and the metal-oxide redox activity. Moreover, microkinetic simulation results showed the chemisorbed CO2 molecule is helpful to the C-H bond activation via reducing the barrier of hydrogen abstraction, even directly abstracting hydrogen as the behavior of surface oxygen site [177]. Meanwhile, the dissociated O* and CO* in CO2 can effectively interact with H*, facilitating the removal of surface hydroxyls, which is the major effect of CO2. On the other hand, considering the high barrier found in the calculations, CO2 is hardly involved in the reverse Boudouard reaction to remove coke. 3.2.3 Fe-based catalysts Iron-based catalysts are widely employed in catalyzing CO2-assisted propane dehydrogenation reactions due to their abundant phases and high CO2 activation capability. Mohammadzadeh et al. [178] discovered 12 wt% Fe impregnated on mesoporous ZrO2 showed highest CO2-ODHP activity compared to other loading contents. This can be contributed to the improved reducibility of the catalyst derived from the strong interaction between Fe2O3 and ZrO2. This interaction protects iron species from being over-reduced to metallic Fe0, but to the Fe3O4 phase [179]. The active oxygen species on Fe3+ sites and Zr4+ sites are responsible for propylene production and side reaction occurs, respectively. The optimal Fe loading enhances the selectivity and stability of catalyst via covering Zr4+ sites, because the balanced acidic-basic property promotes the co-adsorption of propane and CO2 [179], similar with the FeCrO x bulk catalyst [180]. Furthermore, the direct doping of Fe, Ni, Mn, Ti species into CeO2 lattice induces the changes of physicochemical properties (redox, oxygen defects, texture, etc.) [181]. The oxidative capacity of lattice oxygen primarily determines the catalytic activity and product distribution. Dry-reforming occurs on Ni-doped CeO2, while Fe-doped CeO2 mainly undergoes oxidative dehydrogenation. This is because the Fe-enriched surface favors the suppression of the side reactions such as cracking and dry-reforming for C‐C bond scission [182]. Combining Fe species with other metals to form bimetallic alloys promotes CO2-ODHP, and the presence of Fe3O4 suppresses the deep cracking reaction of propane [147,153]. Bimetallic FeNi-based catalysts showed high selectivity for CO2-ODHP, which can be tuned by the oxygen defect content of support as well as the Ni content. Wang et al. [183] discovered the essential role of defects in the ceria on the Fe-Ni active site (Fig. 12 ). As for defect-rich CeO2, it prefers to form Ni-FeO x interface which benefits to selectively scission of C‐H bond for obtaining high propylene yield. Conversely, FeNi alloy is easily generated on the surface of defect-deficient CeO2, the alloy readily induces the activation of C‐C and C=O bond for dry-reforming. DFT analysis indicated the bulk Fe3Ni(111) surface and the FeO/Ni interface favor the scission of C‐H bonds in propane for CO2-ODHP pathway [184]. Zhang et al. [185] provided comprehensive insights into the synergistic effect of Zn and Fe in the CO2-ODHP due to their remarkable abilities in activating propane and CO2. The ZnFe2O x /S-1 exhibited better propylene selectivity and stability than the monometallic catalysts. Characterization results showed the reduction of iron species at initial reaction period initiates the catalytic activity. The ZnFe2O4 precursor and the formation process of α-Fe from the inside to the outside under reaction conditions effectively delay the loss of Zn species and the rapid reduction of iron oxide. In addition, the synergistic effect of V and Fe species could improve the reducibility of catalysts [186,187]. Fe sites take in charge for the activation of CO2 while V sites dominantly contribute for propane dehydrogenation. The C=O bond in CO2 is dissociated on Fe sites to produce O* species for supplying the active lattice oxygen species, that can restore the structure of catalyst to enhance the propane oxidative dehydrogenation ability. 3.2.4 Ga-based catalysts The catalytic behavior of gallium species is closely related to the acidic property and topological structure of support. SiO2 with different texture characteristics were adopted as supports for gallium species, the different CO2-ODHP activities are attributed by the presence of various Brønsted acid centers and adsorption abilities, correlating with the specific surface area [188]. The optimal 7Ga/SiO2 exhibited a propane conversion of 33% with propylene selectivity of 84% and a more than 20 h of stable catalyst life. While Ga/HZSM-5 exhibited a higher CO2-ODHP activity than those of other supports (SiO2, ZrO2, Al2O3, SIRAL 40, TiO2) [189]. The activity is contributed to the active [GaH]2+ species and the lowest activation energy resulting from the Lewis-Brønsted acid pairs formed by the interaction between HZSM-5 and Ga species. Although [GaH]2+ cation is the catalytically active center for propane dehydrogenation [190], [GaH2]+-H+ cation pairs originated from the reaction of H2 with [GaH]2+ cation would inhibit the reaction rate. While in situ DRIFT experiment evidenced that CO2 co-feeding promotes the Ga δ+-H x species transform to Ga3+-O pairs and regenerates the active sites for C‐H bond activation [191]. Except of the elimination of Ga δ+-H x species, CO2 addition effectively improves selectivity and stability via suppressing coke formation, while highest coke content is obtained with H2 addition [189]. The catalysts are generally synthesized by the impregnation due to simple and quick, but the unfavorable issues such as uneven distribution of active species and agglomeration blocking the support channels result in the low catalytic activity. Rownaghi and co-workers developed various strategies to construct dual-function Ga-based catalyst to address them [192–194]. For instance, they synthesized mixed metal oxides Ga-M (M = V, Zr)/ZSM-5 by 3D printing method, which changes the surface properties of the catalysts and the bulk oxide dispersion, benefiting the catalyst reducibility and CO2-ODHP performance [194]. In comparison to impregnation, the atomic layer deposition method (ALD) enhances the interaction between Ga and Al2O3, and moderates the acidity. Consequently, the CO2-ODHP activity (38% conversion and 82% selectivity) was improved due to the energy barrier of C–H bonds decreases, with CO2 facilitates hydrogen consumption via the RWGS reaction [195]. In addition, the Ga3+-single sites in Sibeta zeolite was obtained by two-step post-synthesis method [196]. The well-defined Ga3+ sites in Sibeta are related with weak and medium-strength Lewis sites that can determine for the target product. Apart from gallium oxides, GaN has excellent thermal conductivity and stability, thereby preventing the formation of hot spots and carbon deposits. Those properties have been widely discussed for its application in CO2-ODHP reactions by Liu's group recently [197]. The small GaN nanoparticles can disperse well on the narrow-pore-rich SiO2 support. This benefits the generation of more medium-strong acidic sites from surface coordinately unsaturated Ga3+ species, and enhances the efficient affinity to CO2 with the support, resulting in 31% propane conversion with 93% propylene selectivity. As for NaZSM-5 support, the acidic-basic property is varied with the Si/Al ratios, influencing both activity and the adsorption of CO2, propane, and propylene [198]. The loaded GaN species can generate the strong interaction with support via Si-O-GaN linkage, covering the acidic sites of NaZSM-5 to inhibit the side reactions. Meanwhile, GaN favors the activation of C–H bonds in propane and adsorbs the H atom to form Si-O-GaN-H, which can be consumed by CO2. The Si-O-GaN linkage formed by dispersed GaN with the Si-OH group was also observed in various porous-structural SiO2 (SBA-15, MCF, KIT-6, S-1) [199]. As for microporous S-1, although it exhibits well adsorption capacity for propane, it faces challenges in mass transfer in CO2-ODHP. In contrast, KIT-6 with its 3D interconnected mesopores effectively addresses this issue among the three mesoporous supports. The GaN/KIT-6 showed excellent dehydrogenation performance contributed by the lower apparent activation energy that resulted from the synergistic effect of exposed active site and mass transfer. To improve the activity of GaN/S-1, Fe atoms were doped into the framework of S-1 to promote the generation of silanol nests [200]. And GaN nanocrystallites were implanted via a combined wet impregnation with an in situ nitridation method. The GaN nanoparticles with smallest size (2.7±0.4 nm) on 5GaN/2000-Fe-silicalite-1 exhibits great anti-sintering ability due to the strong interaction and confinement in the Fe-silicalite-1 matrix. Characterization results revealed that the GaN nanoparticles, the size of which is tuned by the molar ratio of Si/Fe, is related to the adsorption and activation of propane, and the isolated framework Fe sites response to the activation of CO2 (Fig. 13 ). The CO2-ODHP reactions, occurring on GaN/Fe-silicalite-1, involves a two-step coupling reactions. 3.2.5 V-based catalysts The multivalence characteristic of vanadium endows it with excellent redox properties, making it an ideal active component for redox reaction catalysts, particularly in CO2-ODHP reactions. Unlike VO x /La-modified mesoporous Al2O3 catalyst resulted in the worse propylene yields than VO x /Al2O3 [201], Ma et al. [202] developed a La-modified V-based catalyst supported on mesoporous silica-based nanospheres for microwave catalytic CO2-ODHP reaction. The modification of La species improves the conversion due to the high dispersion of active VO x species, the percentage of V5+ and the weak acidic sites are improved as well. Meanwhile, the apparent activation energy by microwave-catalysis is decreased nearly half in comparison to that of thermal-catalysis (132.7 to 71.4 kJ mol−1). Similarly, the addition of second metals (Cu, Fe, Ce) effectively promotes the dispersion of both two metal species and the surface density of active V5+ species, exposing more acidic and basic sites for the adsorption of propane and CO2, respectively [186,203–205]. And the existence of doped metals benefits the dissociation of C=O bond for RWGS reaction. In addition, the In-O-V structure and the degree of oligomerization on VO x -In2O3 catalysts play a crucial role in improving selectivity and stability [206,207]. Characterization results indicated monovanadate has a stronger interaction with In2O3 than that of polyvanadate. The In-O-V structure and dispersed VO x species prevents the reduction of In2O3 and neutralizes the excessive basic site from In2O3. Thus, the catalysts with V species loaded below monolayer coverage demonstrates high propene selectivity and stability. Meanwhile, as the additional active site for redox reaction, VO x species enhanced the dehydrogenation activity via utilizing CO2. Lang and co-workers [208,209] evidenced V species were successfully doped into the framework of pure silica-based supports, and the surface density of V species increases as the metal loads, as well as the polymerization of V species. While the isolated V species is more active for dehydrogenation than polymerized VO x species, and it can be completely restored after several cycles of reaction with air regeneration. Investigating the activities of VO x -loaded different supports revealed the crucial role of bridge oxygen in V-O sites for propane activation under reductive conditions (Fig. 14 ) [210]. The lower electron density of bridge oxygen derived from the weaker VO x -support interaction enhances C‐H bond scission ability. Moreover, the oxygen atoms in V=O, V–O–V and V–O–Si bonds favor to hydrogen abstraction, which would be affected by switching from oxidizing to reduction/reaction conditions [211]. The partial reduction occurs in dimeric/small oligomeric vanadia species, while CO2 activates propane by replenishing active lattice oxygen in reduced VO x [210]. It was speculated that ODH and DDH occur in parallel or follow a two-step pathway with a subsequent RWGS reaction [211]. Gambo et al. [204] further decoupled the complex reaction network of CO2-ODHP via thermodynamic analysis. Limiting the tendencies of C–C cleavage pathways, including dry-reforming and cracking reactions, poses a challenge as they are much active than dehydrogenation reactions at 400–600 °C. Additionally, coking reaction resulted in the catalyst deactivation is highly active at 200–1000 °C. Therefore, effective kinetic control is necessary for catalyst design through constructing catalytic surfaces with suitable active sites to limit these undesired reactions. 3.2.6 Other metal-based catalysts Recently, there has been relatively less research on transition metal (Co, Mo, Zn, In, etc.) materials catalyzing CO2-ODHP. Deng et al. [212] successfully incorporated Co species into the framework of S-1 in a one-step process, and obtained the high and stable propane dehydrogenation activity, which is attributed to the confined tetrahedral Co2+ species. Meanwhile, the introduction of CO2 prevents the deep-reduction of Co2+ species to metallic Co species. As for bimetallic catalyst, cobalt species play a crucial role in dispersing and decreasing the size of Pt supported Sibeta zeolite [156]. The increased silanol group and optimized Pt/Co ratios boost the activity and stability as well as the anti-aggregation of particles. In the case of the Pt-In-Co ternary alloy structures and high-entropy intermetallics (PtCoNi)(SnInGa) on ceria, the doping of Co species decreases the energy barriers of C–H bond and CO2 activation via supporting a high density of states near the Fermi level, while inhibits undesired reactions [157,158]. Yang et al. [213] explored the relationship of activities with the properties of ZnO-ZrO2 catalysts. The mixed phases (monoclinic and tetragonal) were observed on ZrO2, which shifts towards a tetragonal-dominated phase upon the addition of the Zn precursor. However, excessive Zn addition results in the separation phase of ZnO from Zn x Zr1–x O2–x . Characterization results indicated the number and mobility of oxygen species derived from lattice defects increase with the formation of the solid solution, showing an almost linear correlation between them. The active oxygen species is essential for the activity and stability of catalysts via redox cycles, while coke deposition on oxygen vacancies can deactivate the catalyst by inhibiting the cycle. Moreover, bimetallic Zn-based catalysts exhibit a synergistic effect that benefits the CO2-ODHP reaction by improving CO2 conversion [154]. The doping of Mo species into ZrO2 materials prevents the aggregation of supported ZnO x crystallites [214]. The propane conversion of Zn/Mo-Zr is more than two-fold higher than that of Zn/ZrO2, and the Mo species inhibit the formation of coke. In the case of active MoO3 supported on La2O3-Al2O3 oxides, the addition of La2O3 blocks the acidic sites of Al2O3, that promotes the propylene selectivity whereas the conversion reduces [215]. Meanwhile, the Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic model of CO2-ODHP to C2/C3 over MoO3/La2O3-Al2O3 was further developed, revealing propylene as the favored product due to the lowest activation energy (67.8 kJ mol−1) among the other parallel reactions [216]. The positive effect of CO2 in dehydrogenation reaction towards enhancing propylene selectivity via re-oxidizing the reduced catalyst, as revealed by kinetic modeling. As for active sites of indium species, except of mentioned VO x /In2O3 in section 3.2.5, its modification affects the crystallinity of ZSM-5 and increases the acidity, which further enhances the CO2-ODHP activity [217]. But the excessive loading blocks pore channels and reduces the activity by converting active In3+ sites to In0. Additionally, the Ti-O-Zr sites in Ti-based bimetallic catalysts act as acidic sites for propane dehydrogenation, while the Ti-O-Tl sites favor the scission of C–C bond [218,219]. Considered the energy consumption issue, Liu et al. [220,221] developed a novel BiOI catalyst for photothermally catalyzed CO2-ODHP reaction. Its propylene formation activity is 90 and 9 times higher than those under sole photo- and thermal conditions, respectively. Compared to BiOCl and BiOBr, BiOI exhibited the highest propene formation rate due to its abundant active oxygen species. Meanwhile, the photothermal catalytic activity is facet-dependent, with (001) facets show higher activity than (110) facets. Introduction of activated carbon reduces the band gap of BiOI, promoting effective separation of electron-hole pairs and enhancing activity. An overview of the metal-based catalysts in CO2-ODHP reaction, including reaction parameters and performances, is provided in Table 3 and Fig. 4(b). Due to the easy activation of propane, the operation temperature range of CO2-ODHP is lower than that for CO2-ODHE. Although Pt- and Cr-based catalysts show excellent dehydrogenation performance, they are hindered by high costs and environmental toxicity, respectively. Currently, catalysts including redox-type metals (V, Fe, etc.) and main group metals (Ga, In, etc.), exhibit well potential in CO2-ODHP reaction, whereas the performances need further improvement. Researchers are focusing on introducing promoters, optimizing support materials, and exploring novel synthesis methods to enhance catalytic performance. Advanced in-situ characterization techniques are also being employed to accurately identify and track the evolution of active sites, aiming to systematically regulate the microstructure of catalysts. In summary, future research on CO2-ODHP catalysts will concentrate on precise control of catalyst structures and in-depth analysis of the dynamic behavior of active sites. 3.3 CO2-assisted butane/butene dehydrogenation reactions 3.3.1 Fe-based catalysts In the direct dehydrogenation of isobutane reactions, Fe2O3 undergoes gradual reduction and carbonization process (Fe2O3→Fe3O4→FeO→α-Fe→Fe3C). The high activity of Fe3C for dry-reforming promotes coke deposition at low CO2/i-C4H10 ratios [222]. However, Fe3O4 is the main phase at high CO2/i-C4H10 ratios due to the oxidization of CO2, suppressing the over-reduction of iron species. The balanced acidic-basic property in Fe-based catalyst, rather than varying Fe contents, is important for CO2-ODH reactions [223]. Increasing catalyst basicity can enhance its anti-coke ability, but trace acidic sites and strong basic sites hinder the oxidative dehydrogenation of 1-butene to 1,3-butadiene [224]. Zhang et al. [225] explored the n-butane-CO2 coupling dehydrogenation reactions on bulk ZnFe2O x and Fe2O3, clarifying the contribution of the hydrogen-assisted activation pathway to CO2 conversion. Kinetic studies revealed that CO2 saturates the surface of ZnFe2O x , and the high CO2/n-C4H10 ratio microenvironment induces reforming reactions, causing the coking and deactivation of ZnFe2O x . Fe2O3 acts as an oxygen exchange medium between CO2 and n-butane.
