The dynamic oxygen exchange process and the phase change during the cycle test drive the surface reconstruction of Fe2O3 and enhance the catalyst's anti-reduction and anti-coking properties (Fig. 15 ). In addition, as the competitive reaction, dry-reforming also occurs over catalyst with high Ni/Fe ratios, while the catalysts with low Ni/Fe ratios present high selectivity of 1,3-butadiene [226], which can be attributed to the decrease of Ni(111) sites that favor the C‐C bond scission. After exploring the activities of M 1 M 2-doped Fe2O3/Al2O3 (M 1, M 2 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) catalysts [227], researchers found the varied oxygen mobility positively correlates with the TOF values of CO2-ODH of 1-butene following a zero-order kinetic [228]. The oxygen mobility mainly affects CO2 activation, and the Lewis acidic sites on the γ-Al2O3 surface are necessary for dehydrogenation reaction. However, the Brønsted acidic sites in FeVCrO x /Al2O3 lead to undesired isomerization reactions, which can be mitigated by introducing ZnCl2 [228]. Oxygen-rich Ce species or active metals dope in Al2O3, based on a framework-confined strategy, can improve oxygen mobility [229–231]. The doped metal is highly dispersed in the Al2O3 lattice, even to form MAlO x structure that disrupts the original Al2O3 lattice to release more active oxygen species, thereby improving the adsorption and activation of CO2. Additionally, the ratios of Fe3+ as the active site of oxidative dehydrogenation can be increased through constructing mesoporous FeAlO x structures [231]. Moreover, the reaction mechanism involves the first adsorption and activation of 1-butene on the Lewis acidic site of Al2O3 [227]. The α-H atom in 1-butene is captured by the basic site on Al2O3, forming a carbanion. The hydrogen atom is then consumed by lattice oxygen to generate 1,3-butadiene and H2O, resulting in the formation of oxygen vacancy. The oxygen vacancy could adsorb CO2 and be restored, while CO is produced. 3.3.2 Other metal-based catalysts Liu et al. [232] studied the structure evolution of PtMn/SiO2 and its impact on CO2-oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane. They found that partial Mn atoms in PtMn alloy are removed via RWGS reaction, forming a Pt-rich surface, which results in a tenfold increase in n-butane conversion. DFT analysis revealed CO2-assisted dehydrogenation of n-butane on active sites follows the MvK mechanism, where the mobility and storage of oxygen in the catalyst are essential for catalytic activity [233]. Moreover, the influence of different oxidants on the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane over Ni-Mo/Al2O3 catalyst was investigated (Fig. 16 ) [233]. Experiments indicated N2O and CO2 could be the candidates for oxidative dehydrogenation, as they limit the formation of electrophilic oxygen species, while O2 promotes the breaking of C–C bonds to form CO x and light hydrocarbons despite having the lowest activation energy. Reportedly, the initial yield of 1,3-butadiene from CO2-oxidative dehydrogenation of 1-butene is closely related to the Cr6+ content in fresh Cr/SiO2 [234]. The addition of Ce species improves the dispersion of supported Cr species and their interaction with the support, leading to a high Cr6+ density [235,236]. And the CO2 oxidized reduced Cr3+ to Cr6+, increasing the stability of catalyst, whereas the reduction of oxides and the deposition of coke are still inevitable. The activity of CO2-ODH of 1-butene over isolated V species surpasses that over polymerized VO x [237]. Silica-based materials, such as SBA-15, MCM-41, are favored due to their high specific surface area and ordered pore structure [237,238]. In VO x -doped MCM-41, the CO2-ODH activity of isobutane shows an almost linear relationship with surface vanadium species despite the coexistence of isolated and polymeric V species at a high loading [238]. Additionally, characterization results indicated that the activity of ZnO species in catalyzing isobutane dehydrogenation to isobutene with CO2 is correlated with the number of acidic sites derived from dispersed ZnO species [239,240]. And silanol nests in S-1 are responsible for the dispersion of ZnO, which could be tuned by controlling the particle size, resulting in higher activity compared to ZnO supported on SBA-15. The catalytic performances of the metal-based catalysts are shown in Table 4 and Fig. 4(c). Compared to CO2-ODHP and CO2-ODHE reactions, CO2-assisted butane/butene dehydrogenation results in more complex product distribution. Additionally, besides more severe cracking and coking side reactions, isomerization reactions must also be considered and suppressed. Notably, the olefin yield in the presence of CO2 is higher than that in direct dehydrogenation system, while co-feeding CO2 is responsible for prolonging the catalysts life. According to the literature, the oxidative effect of CO2 cannot fully restore the performance of deactivated catalysts, and air regeneration is mainly used for this purpose. Moreover, the oxygen species in CO2 is also difficult to participate in the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction. In the CO2-assisted butane/butene dehydrogenation, the development of catalysts not only requires precise synthesis strategies but also necessitates in-situ optimization of the active site structure in reaction atmospheres to enhance the activity and stability of reaction sites. 4 Summary and perspectives The integrated process of light alkanes dehydrogenation and CO2 reduction, which yields light olefins and syngas (CO and H2), offers a dual advantage: efficient conversion of shale gas and petrochemical by-products, along with high-value utilization of greenhouse gases. Herein, we summarized recent studies on the oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes (C2-C4) with CO2. Currently, noble metal-based and Cr-based catalysts have been extensively studied in CO2-ODH reactions and exhibit excellent catalytic performance as shown in Fig. 4. They draw attention due to the commercial applications in direct dehydrogenation (e.g. the Catofin and FMD-4 processes for Cr-based catalysts, and the Oleflex and PDH processes for Pt-based catalysts). However, the limited availability of noble metals and the environmental risks associated with chromium species have led to a shift in research focus towards transition metals such as iron, vanadium, and zinc as alternative catalysts. Despite their potential, these transition metals have been found to have insufficient dehydrogenation activities and poor thermal stability, making them unsuitable for industrial applications. In comparison to commercial catalysts, cobalt-based and nickel-based catalysts show the potential for the future dehydrogenation catalyst design, although there is limited recent literature on their performance. Cobalt and nickel exhibit high activity for alkanes and CO2, but excessive activation of reactants may trigger undesirable side reactions, such as dry-reforming and deep-creaking, due to C–C bond scission. Therefore, despite decades of development, the design of corresponding efficient catalysts still faces a series of difficulties. The core challenge lies in overcoming catalyst deactivation caused by metal sintering and coke deposition during the reaction. In spite of extensive efforts focused on enhancing the resistance of active components to sintering through the design of novel catalysts, including support confinement effects, dopant doping, defect engineering, and other strategies, there remains a relative scarcity of specific studies on the mechanisms of sintering and coking of catalysts under actual reaction conditions. Meanwhile, the complexities of the evolutions of catalyst structure and coking reactions limit our understanding at the molecular level. On the other hand, exploring the in situ modulation of catalyst structure during reactions, particularly focusing on identifying active sites, should be deeply investigated. In a redox atmosphere, surface reconstruction of multi-metallic catalysts may occur due to changes in surface atomic arrangements and imbalances in the migration rates of different metal species. While the metastable structure formed during the reaction exhibits distinct differences from the surface structure of the fresh catalyst, suggesting the possibility of tuning the catalyst surface structure. Consequently, it is essential to recognize that the dynamic surface structure may interfere with the ex-situ characterization results of the active site structure, and therefore, their interpretation should be approached with caution. Henceforth, it is imperative to integrate a variety of advanced in situ characterization techniques (including in situ infrared spectroscopy, in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, in situ X-ray diffraction and others) with systematic theoretical models for monitoring and simulating the dynamic behaviors of active sites during specific induction and deactivation processes (such as carbon deposition, sublimation loss, segregation aggregation, and migration sintering). Concurrently, theoretical calculations of the total reaction network can further elucidate reaction and/or deactivation mechanisms, offering insights for the design of catalysts with long-term stability. Furthermore, limitations in selectively and/or synergistically controlling the activation of C–H, C–C, and C=O bond hinder the expansion of applications for the coupling conversion of alkanes with CO2. Compared with direct dehydrogenation, the introduction of CO2 undoubtedly complicates the whole reaction network due to various side reactions. Thus, it is essential to explore bifunctional catalysts for simultaneously activating alkanes and catalyzing CO2 reduction. Given the limitations of single metal sites in meeting practical demands, collaboration with supports and/or promoters, in addition to the regulation of metal size, is necessary to achieve multi-component activation. Thus, constructing complex catalysts based on bimetallic or multi-metallic systems has been the dominant strategy in catalysts preparation. This strategy aims to achieve efficient conversion of reactants by optimizing interactions between different metal centers. The redox properties of multi-valent metals are crucial for oxidative dehydrogenation reactions, as the involvement of lattice oxygen species can be sustained and replenished from CO2. Therefore, future research should prioritize the sustainability of the lattice oxygen species cycle. For example, scientific modifications such as doping, tuning particle size, and controlling morphology can enhance the storage and release of lattice oxygen species in CeO2. In short, optimizing the structure and composition of catalysts, particularly promoting synergies between metal sites, alongside gaining a deeper understanding and regulation of lattice oxygen cycling mechanisms, will be pivotal pathways to enhance CO2 activation. As an ideal bifunctional catalyst, it should possess targeted sites for selective adsorption of alkanes and CO2, thereby avoiding negative effects from competitive adsorption. Meanwhile, it should contain specific active sites (e.g. the interfaces between metal species with support) that synergistic activate alkanes and CO2. In addition, numerous effective catalysts have been developed to date, the investigation of traditional catalysts is labor-intensive, requiring substantial time and resources. As an important driving force for the revolution of science, technology and industry, artificial intelligence (AI) can be applied for the catalytic fields including CO2-ODH. Data-driven AI can comprehensively analyze catalytic reactions across various variables, and continuously refining designs through algorithms. Contributed to it, the potential catalyst components can be quickly designed, which is of great significance for saving development costs and accelerating the discovery of cheap and efficient catalysts. The application of AI technology is inseparable from massive accurate data, deviations in the training data will lead to inaccuracies in the prediction results, thus it is crucial to establish a high-quality and highly reliable database. Meanwhile, AI should be supported by high-power algorithms for quick iteration, which would also increase the expenditure. Last but not least, the challenges of product separation and utilization must be addressed, as complex reaction networks lead to mixtures containing various products (olefins, CO, H2, H2O, and others), as well as residual reactants (alkanes and CO2). In addition to achieving high conversions of both reactants, comprehensive consideration of energy efficiency and the life cycle assessment of the entire technological chain is essential to achieve zero carbon emissions. Proposed strategies involve the direct use of mixtures as feedstock for downstream chemicals in one step, such as obtaining oxygenates from formylation or aromatics from aromatization [33,241]. However, flexible and controllable adjustment of the olefin/CO/H2 ratio is a prerequisite for efficient tandem and cooperative catalysis between different processes, which also brings great challenges in regulating the surface composition and structure of the catalyst. In addition to exploring reaction pathways, the design and development of harmless and sustainable catalysts should be paid more attention, aiming at decreasing pollution while ensuring catalytic activity. In summary, the future research on alkane-CO2 coupling conversion will focus on achieving high efficiency, environmental friendliness, and diversification in conversion methods. Xiangxue Zhu , Chair Professor at the Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics (DICP), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS). Prof. Zhu received his Ph.D. in Industrial Catalysis from DICP, CAS in 2006 and has been working in the Division of Fossil Conversion and Applied Catalysis at DICP since then. His research interests primarily focus on zeolite synthesis and catalysis, shape-selective catalysis, catalysis and catalytic materials for chemicals, and CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes. Numerous catalytic processes developed by him and his research team have been implemented in over 30 industrial units. Xiujie Li , Professor at the Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics (DICP), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS). Prof. Li received her Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry from DICP, CAS in 2008 and has been working in the Division of Fossil Conversion and Applied Catalysis at DICP since then. Her research interests primarily focus on the synthesis and applications of zeolites for heterogeneous catalysis and VOCs removal, CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes, and developing new routes for value-added olefin on basis of fossil energy and renewable energy. She has published more than 80 peer-reviewed papers.

coredata.dc:description: Light olefins are important platform feedstocks in the petrochemical industry, and the ongoing global economic development has driven sustained growth in demand for these compounds. The dehydrogenation of alkanes, derived from shale gas, serves as an alternative olefins production route. Concurrently, the target of realizing carbon neutrality promotes the comprehensive utilization of greenhouse gas. The integrated process of light alkanes dehydrogenation and carbon dioxide reduction (CO2-ODH) can produce light olefins and realize resource utilization of CO2, which has gained wide popularity. With the introduction of CO2, coke deposition and metal reduction encountered in alkanes dehydrogenation reactions can be effectively suppressed. CO2-assisted alkanes dehydrogenation can also reduce the risk of potential explosion hazard associated with O2-oxidative dehydrogenation reactions. Recent investigations into various metal-based catalysts including mono- and bi-metallic alloys and oxides have displayed promising performances due to their unique properties. This paper provides the comprehensive review and critical analysis of advancements in the CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes (C2-C4) on metal-based catalysts developed in recent years. Moreover, it offers a comparative summary of the structural properties, catalytic activities, and reaction mechanisms over various active sites, providing valuable insights for the future design of dehydrogenation catalysts.
